Carter sees U of L, then vice versa

Four-star point guard says trip to Louisville was a 'great experience'

Carter sees U of L, then vice versa

Steve Jones, swjones1@courier-journal.com 12:28 a.m. EST December 2, 2014
Buy Photo

Life center Academy's Traci Carter (11) drives to the basket under pressure from ACD's defense during the first half of play at Seneca High School in Louisville, Kentucky. December 1, 2014(Photo: John Sommers II, John Sommers II/Special to the Courier-Journal)Buy Photo

2 CONNECT 13 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Pervis Ellison knows a thing or two about being a successful basketball player at the University of Louisville. He thinks Traci Carter has what it takes to be one, too.

University of Louisville head coach Rick Pitino watches Life center Academy's Traci Carter (11) drives to the basket under pressure from ACD's defense during the first half of play at Seneca High School in Louisville, Kentucky.     Last SlideNext Slide

    Rick Pitino is the man Carter needs to convince now.

    With Pitino and two U of L assistant coaches watching Monday night at Seneca High School, Carter had 19 points for New Jersey's Life Center Academy in a 77-64 loss to Arlington Country Day of Florida as part of the Bluegrass Showcase.

    Ellison, the former U of L All-American who now coaches Life Center, said Carter has impressed him with his toughness and explosiveness. As the four-star point guard from Philadelphia works back toward full health after a spring knee injury, Ellison thinks Carter would be a worthy recipient of a U of L scholarship offer.

    RELATED: 5-star Terrance Ferguson says Cards are in top 2

    RELATED: 5-star Thon Maker, like Ferguson, visiting U of L

    "I've had the pleasure of watching that young man grow up for the past 10 years, and skill set-wise, he definitely has the ability to play at that level," Ellison said. "He's just coming back. He's extremely explosive; that's the one part of his game that's not quite there yet. This kid can dunk it any kind of way, but you haven't seen that yet. So we're waiting on his explosion and everything to come back, and you can really get an assessment of his game."

    Carter, whose recruitment was stunted this summer while he was rehabbing from surgery on a knee meniscus, was looking strong before fouling out late in the game against Arlington.

    He doesn't have a U of L offer at this point and remains under evaluation by Pitino, who would like to add another guard to his 2015 signing class. He took an unofficial visit to U of L on Sunday to watch practice, two days after Pitino also watched him play in Lexington.

    "It was a great experience, my first time up here (in Louisville)," Carter said. "I liked it a lot. It's a basketball town. I liked (the visit to U of L) a lot. It was beautiful. It was a great practice, and (Pitino) was very involved and very intense."

    Carter said his goal in Monday night's game was to show Pitino "that I could get in the lane and make plays and basically lead my team to a win."

    Although he was dynamic in scoring 13 points in the second quarter, Carter failed to get that win he wanted and left the gym frustrated. He declined to do postgame interviews on the court but was available to talk on the phone later.

    "I played OK," he said. "Actually bad. I had too many turnovers as a point guard."

    Asked whether he thought he had a good showing in front of Pitino, Carter said, "Kind of."

    U of L is one of several schools showing recent interest in Carter, who returned to the court this fall. He's received scholarship offers from St. John's, California and La Salle in a recruitment that basically has started anew in the last month. All the teams recruiting him before he was injured moved on to other targets while he was sidelined for the April and July evaluation periods.

    "This was his summer, so it's fortunate to Louisville, and it's a unique situation that he's still on the table because (if not for the injury) he wouldn't have been on the table," Ellison said. "He's in the process of getting everything back, but you'll see glimpses of everything he can do."

    Ellison, who keeps close on his alma mater, said "there's no question" that Carter, who's ranked No. 94 nationally, can play at the highest levels of NCAA Division I.

    "Louisville is very interested in Traci," he said. "Traci's an elite athlete. He has that Philadelphia toughness. For the folks in Louisville, he will remind you of Russ Smith. He has the ability to score the basketball."

    If Louisville were to make an offer, where would the Cards be on Carter's list?

    "Very high, at the top, one of several at the top of my list," Carter said. " It's a Hall of Fame coach, a great system, and I believe it's my style of play."

    Carter said Pitino's intense practice impressed him.

    "He's a low-tolerance type of guy, so if they didn't know it, he's making them run," Carter said. "He's very involved, and it's very disciplined."

    From Ellison perspective, what would be Carter's interest level in U of L if Pitino decides to make an offer at some point?

    "You can't get no higher in terms of what a university can offer the young man," Ellison said. "I think he's extremely excited. He's going to go home and discuss it with his family. One of the things I respect about Coach Pitino is he prefers to have a sit-down with you, make sure you come and see the facilities, see the environment, see what the program is all about; then he'll make the offer to you. I can appreciate that, and I think Traci appreciates the fact that they've shown interest in him.

    "Him being able this weekend to visit the campus and sit in on a practice, it was beneficial to him from a standpoint of understanding what a program like this is all about."

    Steve Jones can be reached at (502) 582-7176 and followed on Twitter at @SteveJones_CJ.
